The U.S. and Panama have outlined a tentative accord by which Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga would relinquish power in Panama, senior Administration officials said. They said many details still have to be resolved. Page A1

Two million Ethiopians are starving because the Government has so severly barred emergency relief efforts in the country's north, which is ravaged by both drought and war. Much donated food is piling up at ports. A1
Soviet military advisers will remain in Afghanistan to help the armed forces after a Soviet troop withdrawal and Kabul has the right to acquire weapons from any country, President Najibullah said. A1

Labor unrest increased in Poland on the third day of the largest strike in six years. Strikers are demanding pay increases and reinstatement of at least four workers dismissed because of membership in Solidarity. A3

Big cuts in intelligence budgets have been voted by a Senate committee, reportedly because of anger over the Reagan Administration's failure to upgrade surveillance systems needed to verify a new arms treaty. A7
Canada's plan to reduce acid rain from the United States will be the subject of high-level talks, according to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. He said President Reagan had agreed to the discussion. A6

Fair trade rather than free trade will be Washington's new policy, according to economists and political analysts, who say the U.S. will make it tougher for foreign competition to take away business from American companies. A1

Seeking to bar the spread of a virus that has begun to appear in a slight fraction of blood donations, the American Red Cross said it planned to begin testing donated blood for the cancer-causing virus. A1
At least 59 people were injured, three of them critically, in a midair explosion aboard an inter-island airline flight carrying 84 people from Hilo to Honolulu, a Hawaii Government spokesman said. A1

David Packard is giving $2 billion to charities, reflecting a commitment shared with this late wife and their four children. The gift will make the Packard Foundation one of the richest in the country. A1
Ford earned the largest profit ever for an American auto maker in a quarter. The company said earnings in the first quarter totaled $1.62 billion, or $3.31 a share. D1
Aliens are unlikely to win an extension from next Wednesday to Nov. 30 to apply for amnesty. A procedural vote in the Senate indicated an extension has limited support. B4

A $1 billion anti-AIDS program to provide research, education and treatment was approved in the Senate by a vote of 87 to 4. The omnibus bill now goes to the House, where approval is also expected. B4
The Orioles lost their 21st game in a row, setting an American League record. Baltimore was beaten by the Minnesota Twins, 4-2, with just six hits against Allan Anderson and two relief pitchers. B17

In many ways, we've already won, according to the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Politicians say 1988 is the Year of Jackson - the year a black man made a serious bid for President and was taken seriously by voters. A16
Reverend Jackson was asked why Michael S. Dukakis was not campaigning much in Ohio. Mr. Jackson replied, ''He has already been coronated as nominee. So maybe he's focusing on the coronation.'' A16
